TopicTitle: What do you during those 20+ minute burns?

Articles.Content: Browse the web here, hope am paying attention back to the game during end of burn.
Null set.

Turn the physics warp up as far as I can without the whole ship either folding in on itself and exploding or tearing itself apart, then leave that running on mute and fire up the next episode of [insert TV box set here] on another device entirely- I don't do anything else with the PC to avoid running out of RAM (I regularly hit 97% use with over 10GB from KSP and many mods)- and let MechJeb's maneuver execution thing throttle back at the other end. Then I plot the correction burn to fix the trajectory that the hideously long burn made a mess of, and possibly a correction burn for the correction burn after that.

And if you think 20 minutes is bad, I once had a nearly 3 HOUR burn which took almost an entire day as the game was running at 1/4 speed and I was going to OPM Neidon with an efficient but low thrust plasma thruster (and I didn't know you could physics warp under acceleration back then).

What kind of manuevers are requiring a 20 minute burn?  

Longest I've had I think is 3 minutes.   Anything longer and I will tack on more engines

10 minutes ago, SJC_Hacker said:

What kind of manuevers are requiring a 20 minute burn? 

A single nuke pushing a full ISRU rig to Moho.

Not suggesting it, just giving an example.

16 minutes ago, SJC_Hacker said:

What kind of manuevers are requiring a 20 minute burn?  

High-efficiency, low-thrust LV-N ships. It's the way to move large cargos without prohibitive fuel consumption.
Auto-Chess
Chess or piano.
Hybernate
Revert. Moar boosters. Try again.
Listen to the Interstellar soundtrack. Solve a 7x7 Rubik's Cube...twice.

On 7/7/2020 at 11:11 AM, SJC_Hacker said:

What kind of manuevers are requiring a 20 minute burn?  

Longest I've had I think is 3 minutes.   Anything longer and I will tack on more engines

 

 

Ion engines.

On 7/7/2020 at 6:06 PM, fragtzack said:

 What do you during those 20+ minute burns?

Install persistent thrust for the next burn then relaunch the game.

Launch a second instance of KSP to continue on one of the many WIP designs on my list.

Seriously, doesn't everyone do that?

6 hours ago, catloaf said:

Ion engines.

I'm a big "booster" for ion engines (see avatar).  I only discovered quite recently that Alt-period will engage physics warp in space, which permits engines to keep operating.  You can only get a 4-fold speed-up but that helps.

I've had 2-hour burns and longer.  I set a timer on my phone and go do something else for a while.  It's worth it.

Edited July 12, 2020 by Hotel26

On 7/7/2020 at 8:11 PM, SJC_Hacker said:

What kind of manuevers are requiring a 20 minute burn?  

Longest I've had I think is 3 minutes.   Anything longer and I will tack on more engines

 

 

One tips is rescue missions well inside Moho orbits, perfect for ion engines with their low TWR. 

Retrograde rescue outside dress. Granted it was multiple burns but still. 
Youtube or some site on screen two helps, even done burns while working from home 

Edited July 12, 2020 by magnemoe

On 7/8/2020 at 5:55 AM, jimmymcgoochie said:

And if you think 20 minutes is bad, I once had a nearly 3 HOUR burn which took almost an entire day as the game was running at 1/4 speed and I was going to OPM Neidon with an efficient but low thrust plasma thruster (and I didn't know you could physics warp under acceleration back then).

I am horribly embarrassed to say I did not know about it until today. Don't know how I missed that. Anyway, how does it work?

37 minutes ago, Klapaucius said:

I am horribly embarrassed to say I did not know about it until today. Don't know how I missed that. Anyway, how does it work?

Alt + .(>) turns physics warp on in space and on airless bodies. Just be careful with it, it can also cause unintended side effects like your ships turning inside out, parts breaking, parts getting twisted out of shape and general kraken-y stuff like that. Autostruts help with some of it but just make sure your ship is stable and increase the warp gradually to make sure it can take it.
Open up my phone, bubge-watch YouTube, and/or open up Reddit & this forum, hoping for my Inbox gets populated with something worth a look.
Mostly YouTube or other web surfing on a second monitor. RO means large dV requirements, and it's cheaper to skimp out on probe thrusters, so 4-20 minute burns are not atypical.

Grow up, start a family, return to the PC. /s

In all seriousness, when there's a particularly long burn I just stick on Strauss and listen to The Blue Danube. I have a fairly beefy PC - even my 350 part Duna mothership had a flashing yellow/green clock. Anyway, I'm patient, I can wait

if the burn is over an hour, i just use persistent thrust lol.

but before i had that mod, i just... watched youtube lol

Edited July 17, 2020 by JcoolTheShipbuilder
